caption.text: Studies on microplastic (MP) pollution in freshwater biological materials.

cell.text: Intake: 8 n/h, preference for larger MPs (> 1 µm)
Accumulation of about 130 n/g of tissue

Exposure to 1-μm and 100-μm polyethylene particles (12.5–400 mgL
−1
)for 96 h. Ingestion of 1-μm particles led to immobilisation, increasing with dose and time, with an EC
50
of 57.43 mgL
−1
after 96 h

Invertebrates
(
Daphia magna, Chironomus riparius, Physella acuta
, and
Gammarus pulex
)

Intake:
D. magna
up to 6180 n/h,
C. riparius
226 n/h,
P. acuta
118 n/h,
G. pulex
10 n/h.
D. magna
did not ingest 90-µm MPs, but other species preferred larger MPs (>1 µm)

Fish
(
Lates niloticus
and
Oreochromis niloticus
)
Plastics in gastrointestinal tracts of 20% of fish of each species

Fish
(13 species, e.g.
Culter alburnus, C. oxycephaloides
and
Siniperca chuatsi
)
Xiangxi Bay of Three Gorges Reservoir, China

26% of fish samples contained
MPs; polyethylene and nylon identified

Fish
(
Lepomis macrochirus
and
L. megalotis
)
436 sunfish collected; 196 stomachs (45%) contained MPs, mostly fibres (96% of MPs). Fish length significantly correlated to detected MP number
73% of collected fish contaminated by MPs

Fish
(
Esox lucius, Catostomus commersoni, Notropis atherinoides, Pimephales promelas
, and
Eucalia inconstans
)
83% of fish had MPs (mostly fibres) inside guts
